abstract: Not long ago, many were leery of using their real names on the Web, let alone sharing personal details about their shopping and habits. But a new wave of start-ups are exploiting a mood of online openness, despite possible dangers.
snippet: Not long ago, many were leery of using their real names on the Web, let alone sharing personal details about their shopping and habits. But a new wave of start-ups are exploiting a mood of online openness, despite possible dangers.
lead_paragraph: Mark Brooks wants the whole Web to know that he spent $41 on an iPad case at an Apple store, $24 eating at an Applebee’s, and $6,450 at a Florida plastic surgery clinic for nose work.

headline.main: For Web’s New Wave, Sharing Details Is the Point

abstract: Over the past couple of years, Hadoop has turned into the Justin Bieber of megascale data center software, with just about every Web company of consequence fawning over its mystical powers. Now a start-up, Datameer, has appeared on the scene as the latest Hadoop groupie.
snippet: Over the past couple of years, Hadoop has turned into the Justin Bieber of megascale data center software, with just about every Web company of consequence fawning over its mystical powers. Now a start-up, Datameer, has appeared on the scene as th...

headline.main: Start-Up Goes After Big Data With Hadoop Helper

abstract: On this week’s Bits blog the missing iPhone consumed the discussion during the early part of the week, then commentary moved to privacy, or lack thereof, on Google and Facebook.
snippet: On this week’s Bits blog the missing iPhone consumed the discussion during the early part of the week, then commentary moved to privacy, or lack thereof, on Google and Facebook.
lead_paragraph: As the week comes to a close iPhonegate continues to captivate the country; stores remain closed, truckers can’t buy gasoline, life is essentially at a standstill … O.K., it didn’t really captivate the country, but the missing iPhone did make it onto almost every major media outlet, including “Good Morning America” and “Late Show With David Letterman.” Still, in the nerdosphere, the debate continues among technologist and gadget blogs. But what did commenters on The Times Web site think? Many believed that the entire production was just another Apple publicity stunt.

headline.main: Comments of the Week: iPhonegate, Privacy and Facebook
